questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman reports a 2-year history of chronic pelvic pain. She describes the pain as intermittent, throbbing, and more intense at the time of her menses. It radiates to her back on both sides. She has dyspareunia on deep penetration but no dysuria or dyschezia. She has had one pregnancy culminating in a full-term vaginal delivery and is not currently seeking another pregnancy.
On bimanual examination, she has diffuse tenderness, particularly on the left side. She has no palpable pelvic masses. A cervical smear is normal, and cervical cultures are negative. Urinalysis is within normal limits, and a pregnancy test is negative. The patient's BMI is 22.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Trigger-point injection
A trial of oral contraceptive pills and ibuprofen
Cystoscopy
Laparoscopy
Pelvic CT

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trigger-point injections are used to diagnose and treat myofascial pathology.

B) CORRECT:

Pelvic endometriosis affects between 15% and 25% of all women of reproductive age. Although not all women with pelvic endometriosis have signs and symptoms of the disease, those who do often have chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and debilitating menstrual periods. In severe cases, patients may also have symptoms related to involvement of the bowels or urinary system.

In the absence of palpable pelvic pathology, especially in a woman with a normal BMI and no current plans for pregnancy, pelvic pain can be treated empirically with hormonal contraceptive regimens (such as oral contraceptive pills, hormone-containing intrauterine devices, or injections of medroxyprogesterone acetate) in combination with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial strategy for a patient with chronic pelvic pain and suspected pelvic endometriosis who is not contemplating pregnancy is a trial of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and hormonal contraception.

C) INCORRECT:

Although cystoscopy can be used as a part of the diagnostic process, it is generally reserved for patients with urinary symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

If the pain persists and is unresponsive to conservative medical management, the most appropriate next step is diagnostic laparoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography is indicated when palpable pelvic masses, such as endometriomas, are present. It does not detect peritoneal endometriosis. CT of the pelvis is not a first-line radiographic imaging option in this setting and would only be needed as follow-up if there was suspicion for cancer on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of severe right-sided pelvic pain that began 3 hours ago. She reports her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. On examination, she appears pale and diaphoretic with blood pressure 88/62 mmHg, heart rate 118 bpm, and temperature 98.4°F. She has right lower quadrant tenderness with involuntary guarding. Point-of-care ultrasound shows echogenic free fluid in the pelvis, and her serum beta-hCG is positive. What is the most appropriate immediate action?

choices.text: Consult obstetrics for emergency surgery
Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
Start IV fluids and observe for clinical improvement
Administer oral analgesics and discharge with return precautions
Perform transvaginal ultrasound for further evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of positive pregnancy test, sudden severe pelvic pain, hemodynamic instability, and free fluid in the pelvis indicates ruptured ectopic pregnancy with hemorrhage. This is an immediately life-threatening cause that requires emergency surgical intervention to control bleeding and prevent further deterioration.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan would delay definitive management in a hemodynamically unstable patient with clear clinical evidence of intraabdominal hemorrhage. Additional imaging is not needed when the diagnosis is evident from clinical presentation and point-of-care ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

 IV fluids alone would not address the underlying cause of hemorrhage and would not provide definitive treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral analgesics and discharge would be inappropriate and dangerous for a hemodynamically unstable patient with signs of intraabdominal hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound would provide additional diagnostic information but would delay necessary treatment in a hemodynamically unstable patient where the clinical presentation already suggests ruptured ectopic pregnancy requiring immediate surgical management.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset severe left lower abdominal pain that began 6 hours ago after sexual intercourse. She has nausea and reports her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 95; R, 18; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness without peritoneal signs. She is hemodynamically stable but appears uncomfortable. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study to guide further testing?

choices.text: Point-of-care ultrasound for free fluid
Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel
CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
β-hCG level
Transvaginal ultrasound with Doppler

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Point-of-care ultrasound for free fluid may be useful but should follow pregnancy testing. The interpretation and urgency of findings differ significantly based on pregnancy status, with free fluid being more concerning in a pregnant patient.

B) INCORRECT:

While complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are part of the diagnostic workup, determining pregnancy status takes priority as it identifies or excludes critical diagnoses like ruptured ectopic pregnancy and can help determine the appropriate imaging modality.

C) INCORRECT:

CT imaging would expose a potentially pregnant patient to ionizing radiation. Determining pregnancy status is required to guide appropriate imaging choices and help avoid unnecessary fetal radiation exposure.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- β-hCG must be obtained first in all women of reproductive age to determine pregnancy status, as it can fundamentally change the differential diagnosis. A positive result raises concern for ectopic pregnancy rupture, requiring immediate further evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound with Doppler is appropriate for evaluating adnexal pathology but should be performed after the patient's pregnancy status has been determined. The type of ultrasound needed depends on whether the patient is pregnant.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with severe left-sided pelvic pain that started 6 hours ago while running. She reports intermittent nausea and one episode of vomiting. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago, and she uses oral contraceptives. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 88; R, 18; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). She appears uncomfortable but alert. Abdominal examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness without rigidity. Pelvic examination shows left adnexal fullness with moderate tenderness. Urine pregnancy test is negative. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Initiate empiric antibiotic therapy
Obtain transvaginal ultrasound with Doppler
Order CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Administer ketorolac and discharge with gynecology follow-up
Obtain serum β-hCG and complete blood count

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The unilateral nature of the pain, absence of fever, and no cervical motion tenderness make an infection (e.g., pelvic inflammatory disease) unlikely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation of sudden severe unilateral pelvic pain during physical activity with adnexal fullness strongly suggests ovarian torsion. Transvaginal ultrasound with Doppler is the appropriate initial imaging study to evaluate ovarian blood flow and confirm the diagnosis, as ovarian torsion requires urgent surgical intervention to preserve ovarian function.

C) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is less sensitive than transvaginal ultrasound for evaluating ovarian pathology and would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.

D) INCORRECT:

Pain management and outpatient follow-up would be inappropriate given the severity of symptoms and clinical findings suggestive of ovarian pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies may provide supportive information but will not help establish the diagnosis in this patient. The negative urine pregnancy test has already excluded pregnancy-related causes, and delaying diagnostic imaging could compromise ovarian viability if torsion is present.
